description: From Middle English bache, bæcche (“bank, sandbank”), from Old English beċe (“beck, brook, stream”), from Proto-West Germanic *baki, from Proto-Germanic *bakiz (“brook”), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰog- (“flowing water”).
Cognate with Dutch beek (“brook, stream”), German Bach (“brook, stream”), Swedish bäck (“stream, brook, creek”). More at batch, beck.

entries.meaning: The shore of a body of water, especially when sandy or pebbly.
A horizontal strip of land, usually sandy, adjoining water.
(UK dialectal, Sussex, Kent) The loose pebbles of the seashore, especially worn by waves; shingle.
(sports) A dry, dusty pitch or situation, as though playing on sand.
examples: I never realised Lincoln was a seaside town. BRIAN LAWS Scunthorpe manager, after losing on a liberally sanded beach of a pitch

verbs.description: beach (third-person singular simple present beaches, present participle beaching, simple past and past participle beached)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To run aground on a beach.
examples: When we finally beached, the land was scarcely less wet than the sea.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To run (something) aground on a beach.
examples: Great Aías led twelve ships from Sálamis
and beached them where Athenians formed for battle.

entries.meaning: (of a vehicle) To run into an obstacle or rough or soft ground, so that the floor of the vehicle rests on the ground and the wheels cannot gain traction.
